conversation.text: Let's make some simple mashed potatoes
What's the first step?
First thing would be to choose what type of potatoes you want to use.
Oh! All I have on hand are russets. Is that okay?
Perfect. Russets are great for making a light, fluffy mashed potato.
evidence: Russets, are high in starch which creates light and fluffy mashed potatoes

conversation.text: Well that was a stroke of luck. Okay, what should I do now?
How many people are you cooking for?
Just me and my partner.
Okay, then I would recommend between six to eight medium-sized potatoes. How does that sound to you?
All right then, your're the boss. I suppose I should go for eight. It's better to have too much than too little and if there are any leftovers I can use it for lunch tomorrow.
Are your potatoes prewashed or not?
No, lol! They're pretty dirty!
Okay, you're going to want to wash them thoroughly. Put your potatoes in a basin of cold water and make sure they're fully immersed.
evidence: Use cold water and gently scrub the entire potato

conversation.text: Done. So I just swish them around, right?
Yes, make sure you get all the dirt off. A good idea is using a small brush to get any stubborn dirt off.
evidence: You can use a small brush

conversation.text: Right so, they are all looking sparkly clean. What's next?
Next you'll want to peel off the skins and cut the potatoes into little cubes of roughly the same size.
I'll do my best. Does it matter if they're not all the same size?
They don't have to be exact but if they're all near enough the same size then they'll all take the same time to cook.
I get you. What's after that?
Put all your potatoes in a saucepan and fill with cold water. Make sure there is at least an inch or two of water above the potatoes.
evidence: large saucepot and fill with cold water

conversation.text: Done and done. Next?
Pop it on the stove, bring to a boil.
evidence: Bring the water to a boil

conversation.text: Okay. The pot is now boiling.
Perfect. Turn down your stove to a medium heat and let them simmer for 1o to 20 minutes. Now is a good time to add a dash of salt to the water.
evidence: reduce the heat to a lively simmer

conversation.text: I just pricked them with a fork and it went in easy enough. Does that mean they're done?
When you say easy, how easy is easy?
Just the lightest of pressure and the fork went straight through.
Oh yeah they are done! Next you're going to want to drain the water. Place a collander in your sink and empty the pot into the collander.
Almost splashed boiling water all over myself but I got it done. Should I put the potatoes back in the saucepan?
Yes indeed. We're now ready to mash. Now would you like to just mash the potatoes as is, or add some butter, or milk, or both?
Oh gosh. I'm not sure. What do you think?
Can't go wrong with butter.
Ha! That's true I suppose. How much should I add?
Okay cut a good chunk of butter and drop it into the pot with the potatoes. Can you let me know when it's nearly completely melted?
Yes it has. Should I start mashing now?
Yes, your best bet is to use a masher or even a good sized fork. Mash until there are no visible lumps and they begin to form a uniform consistency.
Oh wow, they smell amazing. These look done, are they done now? They must be right?
Well how about you take a wee bite and let me know what you think?
Oh my God they're amazing!
Ha! That's good to hear. So is there anything else I can do for you?
No, thank you so much though and I'm off to stuff my face now I guess.
Enjoy!
Oh I definitely will. Bye!

recipe.title: How to Make Simple Mashed Potatoes

procedure.description: There are a few basic options when it comes to buying potatoes: baking, boiling, and all-purpose potatoes. All have different qualities when it comes to flavor and texture. Baking potatoes, such as Russets, are high in starch which creates light and fluffy mashed potatoes. Boiling potatoes, such as red potatoes, are considered waxy which means they hold their shape and may create lumpy mashed potatoes. All-purpose potatoes, such as Yukon Golds, fall in between boiling and baking potatoes in terms of texture. They do offer a butterier flavor than Russets.

Use cold water and gently scrub the entire potato. Look for dark patches where dirt might have settled. If you wash the potatoes in a bowl of water, be sure to rinse them before cutting. You can use a small brush specifically designated for cleaning potatoes or produce. This will help scrub away any dirt that's firmly stuck.

You can cook the potatoes with the skins on or you can peel them before cutting them. Simply cut your potato into quarters or cubes. Leaving the skins on will give your mashed potatoes more texture. For this reason, you should consider using Yukon Golds, which have a thinner peel than Russets.

Place your prepared potatoes in a large saucepot and fill with cold water. The potatoes should be covered by an inch or two of water. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce the heat to a lively simmer and cook for 10 to 20 minutes. The potatoes are done when you stick a fork into them and they start to fall apart. You can salt your water for extra flavor, just as though you're cooking pasta. The potatoes will absorb the salt as they cook. Avoid using hot water and covering your pot with a lid. This will make the potatoes cook unevenly and can lead to gluey potatoes.

While the potatoes are cooking, heat up chicken stock or milk until warm and get some butter out of the fridge. Use chicken stock if you'd like the potato flavor to really shine. Milk, ranging from skim to whole, will make creamier potatoes. Heating your liquid will keep the mashed potatoes hotter for longer. Warm liquid is also absorbed better by the potatoes.

Use a strainer or lift the potatoes out with a slotted spoon. Return the cooked potatoes to your pot on the stove. Add your room temperature butter and start mashing the potatoes. The best tool for mashing rustic potatoes is a simple potato masher. Avoid mashing too much or you'll be left with more of a puree. You may want to leave small chunks and skin somewhat intact.

Gradually add some of your warm stock or milk. Stir gently and add a bit more liquid if your potatoes are still loose. Keep adding liquid gradually until the potatoes bind together. Avoid adding all your liquid at once. You could end up with too much liquid which makes mushy mashed potatoes. Your potatoes will need more or less liquid depending on potato type and level of starchiness.

Taste the potatoes and add salt, pepper, and/or more butter, as you like. Serve while they're still warm or keep covered until ready to eat. Minced chives or paprika make great garnishes for mashed potatoes.
